questions.questionText: How many lines are in a musical staff?
questions.hint: The staff consists of both lines and spaces.
questions.explanation: A standard musical staff consists of five lines and four spaces.

questions.questionText: Which symbol represents a natural note?
questions.hint: This symbol cancels a sharp or flat.
questions.explanation: A natural sign (♮) cancels any previous sharp or flat on a note.

questions.questionText: Which note is highlighted on the keyboard?
questions.hint: This note is two white keys to the right of C.
questions.explanation: The note E is the second white key in a set of three starting from C.

questions.questionText: What is the interval between C and G?
questions.hint: A perfect fifth consists of seven half steps.
questions.explanation: The interval from C to G is a perfect fifth, spanning seven half steps.

questions.questionText: Which note is displayed on the bass clef?
questions.hint: This note is on the first line of the bass clef.
questions.explanation: In the bass clef, the first line represents the note G.

questions.questionText: Which note is enharmonically equivalent to B♭?
questions.hint: Enharmonic notes sound the same but are written differently.
questions.explanation: B♭ and A# sound the same but are written differently in notation.

questions.questionText: What is the name of the note on the second space of the bass clef?
questions.hint: The spaces in the bass clef spell ACEG.
questions.explanation: The second space in the bass clef represents the note C.

questions.questionText: Which interval spans from D to A?
questions.hint: This interval consists of seven half steps.
questions.explanation: The interval from D to A is a perfect fifth.

questions.questionText: Which clef is commonly used for low-pitched instruments?
questions.hint: This clef is used for left-hand piano notes.
questions.explanation: The bass clef is used for low-pitched instruments like bass guitar and left-hand piano notes.

questions.questionText: Which of these notes is enharmonically equivalent to F#?
questions.hint: This note sounds the same as F# but is written differently.
questions.explanation: F# and G♭ are enharmonic equivalents, meaning they sound the same but are spelled differently.
